DataElement.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Histology Classification Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the systematic arrangement of the cells and constitute tissues of Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts, by classes or groups.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Histology Classification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the systematic arrangement of the cells and constitute tissues of Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts, by classes or groups.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.  There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane.  Currently, DCIS is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis.  The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS. --2002

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

Property.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.:Classification; the grouping of things into classes or categories.

Concepts.definition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Update to use OC DCIS with concept name dw 05-13-2015

ValueDomain.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma in Situ Histology Classification Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the histologic subdivision or classification of Ductal Breast Carcinoma in Situ.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast characterized by the presence of tumor cells which fill the ductal spaces as solid sheets.

Concepts.longName: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, Non-Comedo Type
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of sheets of tumor cells without evidence of central necrosis or cell death.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A high grade carcinoma characterized by the presence of comedo-type of tumor cell necrosis in which the necrotic areas are surrounded by a solid proliferation of malignant pleomorphic cells.

Concepts.definition: A high grade carcinoma characterized by the presence of comedo-type tumor cell necrosis in which the necrotic areas are surrounded by a solid proliferation of malignant pleomorphic cells.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

DataElement.origin: NSABP CRF:National Surgical Adjuvant Breast and Bowel Project Case Report Form
